TopicTitle: What is a good re-entry altitude from Mun

Articles.Content:
I've become a bit gun shy after having Val burn up coming back from Mun.

So now when my AP is in the 10,000KM range (say returning from Mun), I set my PE to be around 55KM. I then use aerobraking/thrusters to lower my AP to under 1,000KM. But this often takes several orbits and is sort of tedious to micro manage.

Assuming I have a MK1 capsule science JR, misc science, batteries, plus  heat shield.  Is it safe to land directly from the Mun? If so what altitude should I set the PE to be?

If I also have say a Terry upper stage with a several  hundred DV left, when is the best time to fire off the remaining fuel.  When I first hit the atmosphere, at the PE, or when I see first see the parts overheating?

4 minutes ago, strollen said:

I've become a bit gun shy after having Val burn up coming back from Mun.

So now when my AP is in the 10,000KM range (say returning from Mun), I set my PE to be around 55KM. I then use aerobraking/thrusters to lower my AP to under 1,000KM. But this often takes several orbits and is sort of tedious to micro manage.

Assuming I have a MK1 capsule science JR, misc science, batteries, plus  heat shield.  Is it safe to land directly from the Mun? If so what altitude should I set the PE to be?

It's totally safe to land directly from the Mun.  30-35 km is a pretty good Pe from the Mun or Minmus, assuming that:

  1. you have a heatshield
  2. you don't have a super-massive ship hiding behind that heatshield

...i.e. for a typical Mun-return science lander.  This Pe will be perfectly safe with a heatshield, and will take you down to the surface in one pass (no multiple-pass aerobraking).

The main thing is to make sure you have enough stability and/or torque and/or control ability to keep yourself pointed retrograde, with the heatshield between your dainty bits and the blowtorch.  If you've got that Science Jr. slung underneath the command pod, then your ship may be prone to flipping, because you've got the lightweight Science Jr. in front of the relatively heavy command pod.  You'll probably be fine, if you've got at least level-1 SAS (i.e. a HECS-or-better probe core, or a level-1-or-better pilot).  If you set your SAS to "hold retrograde" then you'll probably be fine.

A safer way, less prone to instability, would be to put the heatshield directly below the command pod, and jettison the Science Jr. before coming home.  That will be a nice, aerodynamically stable ship for reentry.  But you should be okay in the above-described configuration, as long as you are careful to stick religiously close to retrograde as you reenter.  (Note that you want to be surface retrograde, not orbit retrograde, so put your navball into surface mode before hitting atmosphere.)

 

11 minutes ago, strollen said:

If I also have say a Terry upper stage with a several  hundred DV left, when is the best time to fire off the remaining fuel.  When I first hit the atmosphere, at the PE, or when I see first see the parts overheating?

Generally speaking, the lower you are when you use it, the better, for maximum use of Oberth effect.  So basically you want to wait as late as you can get away with so that you can burn all the fuel before overheating.  Engines are fairly heat-resistant-- you can actually bring a ship home from the Mun without a heatshield, if it's lightweight and you make good use of body lift.

If you wait until Pe, that may be a bit too late with a 30-35 km Pe.  (My suggestion of 30-35 km is for ships with no retro-burn ability.)  So, a couple of options:

  1. Set your Pe to something a bit higher, like 45 km.  Normally that would not be low enough to go down in one pass, if you're coming back from the Mun.  However, that's high enough that it ought to be survivable for the Terrier.  So you could do that, wait until Pe, burn all your fuel, jettison.  You'll probably coast up to a low Ap one time, then reenter fairly easily.
  2. Use the 30-35km Pe I suggest, but start your retro-burn when you're at around 50 km.

3 hours ago, strollen said:

Assuming I have a MK1 capsule science JR, misc science, batteries, plus  heat shield.  Is it safe to land directly from the Mun? If so what altitude should I set the PE to be?

As @Snark said, a Pe of about 30km will make you land direct from Mun.  However, in my experience, a 1.25m heat shield won't save anything that sticks out more than its diameter.  This means that any radially attached goo pods, barometers, batteries, antennae, etc., need to be on the sloped sides of the Mk1 pod as close to the top as you can manage, and often this isn't workable due to the large hatch area.  Thus, the goo at least will probably burn off the ship.

To prevent this, I find it better to set my Pe to about 38km when returning from Mun.  Nothing seems to burn off the ship this high or above.  But you need multple passes to land and, if you don't still have an engine to circularize and then deorbit once your Ap is low enough, there's no telling where you'll end up landing.  Which can be bad because mountains, darkness, and such things.

Therefore, I try to reenter with an engine and a few hundred dV left.  Engines in 1.0.5 suck as heat shields so anything below about 35km will burn them up.  So what I do is make the 1st pass at 38-39km, then raise my Pe to 40km and do several more passes.  Then circularize, wait for KSC to get in the right place, de-orbit over the desert with my trajectory coming down at or just west of the longitude of Overshoot Island, and all is well.

3 hours ago, strollen said:

If I also have say a Terry upper stage with a several  hundred DV left, when is the best time to fire off the remaining fuel.  When I first hit the atmosphere, at the PE, or when I see first see the parts overheating?

If landing close to KSC is your goal,that's best done from a circular orbit, and takes a couple hundred dV.  So save the fuel to raise your Pe out of the atmosphere once your Ap is low enough, to suit you, then use the rest for the deorbit birn.  And don't go lower than about 38km on the initial few passes or the engine will likely burn up.
